newsitem.title: USA: US money managers long on US debt over past wk - MCM.
newsitem.headline: US money managers long on US debt over past wk - MCM.

text.p: U.S. fixed-income managers were consistently long and reflecting a bullish bias in their positions in U.S. debt markets over the past week, according to an MCM MoneyWatch Inc survey.
"The big guys are long (and) the rest of the pack is catching up," said MCM money market analyst Peter McTeague, who conducts the asset allocation survey.
The weekly survey showed durations as a percentage of benchmark slipped to 108.2 percent in the week ended December 30 from 108.3 percent in the prior week.
A duration reading above 100 percent indicates the group of investors polled is mostly long on the market.
A portfolio's duration represents its average maturity and is used by portfolio managers to calculate exposure to risk.
In the "next likely move" category, portfolio managers representing 24 percent of total assets in the survey said they would "buy," slightly lower from 25 percent the prior week.
Strategists leaning toward "sell" dropped to 10 percent, down from 22 percent in the week ended December 23.
Sixty-six percent of managers said they were "neutral" on the market, up from 53 percent a week ago.
Cash as a percentage of assets fell to 2.20 percent, against 2.36 percent registered the previous week.

The survey showed 32 percent of investors polled overweighted the 10-plus years duration sector, up from 31 percent the previous week, while nine percent underweighted it. The remaining 59 percent were "neutral."
In the five- to 10-year duration sector, 48 percent of investors polled said they overweighted the securities and 11 percent underweighted them.
The survey included 38 domestic participants, who manage about $110 billion in fixed-income assets. The poll is conducted weekly by MCM and usually is released on Tuesday.
